dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Pariah Investments, a hedge fund that bets on companies with the worst workplace ratings, has actually underperformed the market for a decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pariah Investments, a hedge fund that bets on companies with the worst workplace ratings, has actually underperformed the market for a decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, a mutual fund that invests in companies with positive workplace ratings, Parnassus Endeavor, has beaten the market handily over the past 10 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's fascinating—so the whole idea of exploiting workers for profit, it doesn't even pay off financially in the long run?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's fascinating-so the whole idea of exploiting workers for profit, it doesn't even pay off financially in the long run?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And The Unhappy Workers' Union just released their first-ever list of America's most miserable companies to work for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And The Unhappy Workers' Union just released their first-ever list of America's most miserable companies to work for.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Careers site CareerBliss launched its eighth-annual list of the happiest companies in America.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, they actually surveyed disgruntled employees on things like toxic environments and poverty-level pay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, they actually surveyed disgruntled employees on things like toxic environments and poverty-level pay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It surveyed tens of thousands of workers and asked them to rate their employers on ten key factors, such as their relationship with management, workplace environment, compensation, satisfaction with job function and growth opportunities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Keller Williams Realty landed at the very bottom of that list. Apparently they only have like 17 agents across two metro areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Keller Williams Realty landed at the very bottom of that list. Apparently they only have like seventeen agents across two metro areas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Keller Williams Realty takes the top spot. The Austin, Texas company has 175,000 agents across more than 900 metro areas and claims to be the worlds largest real estate franchise by agent count.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously? One employee even said they "fire from within" and discourage people from growing their careers. That's bleak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously? One employee even said they fire from within and discourage people from growing their careers. That's bleak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A Keller Williams Realty employee wrote on CareerBliss.com, One of the greatest benefits is how our company promotes from within. All employees are encouraged and supported to be in control of their growth and career paths.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Nike—ranked second worst. They're pushing this NIKE Direct bankruptcy initiative to cut out retailers entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Nike-ranked second worst. They're pushing this N I K E Direct bankruptcy initiative to cut out retailers entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sneaker king Nike ranks second. In June it announced its NIKE Direct initiativethe company is trying to sell more of its products directly to consumers through its website and own stores, rather than rely on traditional retailers like Foot Locker.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, probably isn't making their employees any happier either. I mean, rapid brand devaluation can't help morale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, probably isn't making their employees any happier either. I mean, rapid brand devaluation can't help morale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It remains one of the most valuable brands in the world, and its navigating a big transition as more consumers shop online.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Adobe made the list too, at number ten. They're getting slammed for a combative atmosphere and unhelpful colleagues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Adobe made the list too, at number ten. They're getting slammed for a combative atmosphere and unhelpful colleagues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adobe is the fourth happiest company, according to CareerBliss. The atmosphere is highly collaborative and energizing. People have always been friendly and helpful; very professional, wrote one employee on CareerBliss.com.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even though they claim PDFs save 90% on costs compared to paper? Doesn't matter if your workplace feels toxic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though they claim PDFs save ninety percent on costs compared to paper? Doesn't matter if your workplace feels toxic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It claims PDFs have led to a 91% reduction in environmental impact and 90% cost savings when compared with paper-based processes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And Amgen came in last among the miserable companies. An employee even mentioned a dreadful on-campus daycare.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And Amgen came in last among the miserable companies. An employee even mentioned a dreadful on-campus daycare.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pharmaceutical giant Amgen ranks fifth. The work-life balance is great, fantastic daycare on campus, lots of smart co-workers, wrote one CareerBliss reviewer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oof. Plus, selling only around $600 of their arthritis drug last year? That can't be good for job security or morale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof. Plus, selling only around six hundred dollars of their arthritis drug last year? That can't be good for job security or morale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Arthritis drug Enbrel is its top-selling product, bringing in nearly $6 billion in sales last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's striking how these companies all seem to have both ethical and performance issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's striking how these companies all seem to have both ethical and performance issues.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really makes you question the whole "exploit to succeed" narrative. Doesn't seem to work for anyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really makes you question the whole exploit to succeed narrative. Doesn't seem to work for anyone.

artist_script:
HostA: Pariah Investments, a hedge fund that bets on companies with the worst workplace ratings, has actually underperformed the market for a decade.
HostB: That’s fascinating—so the whole idea of exploiting workers for profit, it doesn’t even pay off financially in the long run?
HostA: Exactly. And The Unhappy Workers' Union just released their first-ever list of America's most miserable companies to work for.
HostB: Oh wow, they actually surveyed disgruntled employees on things like toxic environments and poverty-level pay.
HostA: Yeah, and Keller Williams Realty landed at the very bottom of that list. Apparently they only have like 17 agents across two metro areas.
HostB: Seriously? One employee even said they "fire from within" and discourage people from growing their careers. That’s bleak.
HostA: And then there’s Nike—ranked second worst. They’re pushing this NIKE Direct bankruptcy initiative to cut out retailers entirely.
HostB: Which, uh, probably isn’t making their employees any happier either. I mean, rapid brand devaluation can’t help morale.
HostA: Adobe made the list too, at number ten. They’re getting slammed for a combative atmosphere and unhelpful colleagues.
HostB: Even though they claim PDFs save 90% on costs compared to paper? Doesn’t matter if your workplace feels toxic.
HostA: Right. And Amgen came in last among the miserable companies. An employee even mentioned a dreadful on-campus daycare.
HostB: Oof. Plus, selling only around $600 of their arthritis drug last year? That can’t be good for job security or morale.
HostA: It’s striking how these companies all seem to have both ethical and performance issues.
HostB: Yeah, it really makes you question the whole "exploit to succeed" narrative. Doesn’t seem to work for anyone.
